title: Chickpea-Lamb Cakes With Red Pepper Sauce
Poached Fruit With Clove Granite And Cookies
Pears Poached In Beaumes-De-Venise And Honey
Apple Chaud-Froid
recipe_yield: Six to eight servings (with sherbet and ice cream left over)

title: Mushrooms in Marsala Wine (Funghi Alla Marsala)

description: Some cheesecakes are the culinary equivalent of a punch in the gut: too sweet, too heavy, too filling. This one, first published in The Times in 1984, is delightfully different. It's lightly-sweet, slightly tangy and gently laced with spiced pumpkin flavor. The texture is surprisingly airy. Serve slices with a dollop of whipped cream or créme fraîche.
title: Pumpkin Cheesecake In Nut Crust
Buttermilk-Marinated Wild Turkey With Peppery Milk Gravy
Sweet-Potato-Custard Pie in Orange Crust
description: This recipe came to The Times in 1995 in a column about the novelist and farmer Dori Sanders, who cooked it for Thanksgiving on her farm in Flibert, S.C.. It is, some say, quite the best thing to do with a sweet potato. "People tell their life stories through food," Ms. Sanders said. "They talk about how they did it then, how they do it now. The way they talk tells you who they are."

title: Thanksgiving Deviled Crab With Oysters Baked On The Half Shell
Hearty Duck And Wild Rice Soup
Roast Turkey With Maple Corn Sauce
Oyster Stuffing
ingredients: Salt, white pepper and red pepper
recipe_yield: About 5 cups, or enough for 2 chickens

title: Sausage Stuffing
recipe_yield: About 5 cups, or enough for 2 chickens

title: Brussels Sprouts With Garlic and Cheese
Potato, Carrot And Celery Root Stuffing
Roast Beets With Sage And Orange Glaze
Turkey Steaks With Prosciutto and Mushrooms
Wild Rice Salad With Sun-Dried Cherries
Amana Smoked Ham in Bread Dough
Obstkuchen (Fruit tarts)
description: Almost any kind of raw or poached fruit can be used, allowing 1 1/2 to 2 cups for each tart.

title: Bang Bang Turkey
description: Here, Thanksgiving leftovers head East. This fast-assembled salad is nothing more than shredded turkey under a satay-like sauce of peanut butter, chile bean and Chinese vinegar, with some shredded lettuce and chopped cucumbers. It’s gloriously wolfable and easy as well.

title: Vietnamese Turkey And Cellophane Noodle Salad
String Beans With Ginger and Garlic
description: Here is a recipe for fresh string beans, boiled just until barely tender and bright green, then tossed in a pan with minced garlic and ginger. The beans can be cooked a day ahead, leaving nothing more to do before the meal than to assemble everything over high heat.

title: Bread Stuffing
recipe_yield: 6 to 8 cups, enough for a 12-pound bird
description: Mark Bittman writes that this bread stuffing, based on a James Beard recipe, has been a staple on his Thanksgiving table for decades. First you make fresh bread crumbs: just whiz a few cups of slightly stale cubes of decent bread (crust and all, unless it’s super-hard) in a food processor. Keep the crumbs very, very coarse. Cook them with plenty of butter (yes, you can use olive oil) and good seasonings. Baked in a pan, this is delicious, with or without gravy. You could use it to stuff the turkey if you’d like — but once you've tried it cooked on its own, you won't look back.

title: Corn Bread and Squash Stuffing
recipe_yield: 6 to 8 cups, enough for a 12-pound bird

title: Mashed Potatoes With Corn and Chives
Stir-Fried Cabbage With Cumin Seeds
description: Cabbage is rarely a side dish on its own, but it is in this recipe. It takes on some Indian flavor with caraway seeds and the garam masala, and it maintains its crunch with the quick heat of the stir fry. It is excellent with lamb.

title: Mirliton, Andouille and Shrimp Dressing
description: This is a typical Thanksgiving dish in southern Louisiana.

title: Broiled Bananas With Lemon and Sugar
Carrots and Turnips With Fried Sage Leaves
Cranberry-Wild Rice Stuffing
description: Bread stuffing is classic for Thanksgiving, but it isn’t the only choice. In this recipe by the cookbook author Nancy Harmon Jenkins, wild rice takes on the starchy role, while sausage and cranberries lend richness and tang. You can mix the elements together one day ahead, then bake just before serving.

title: Chestnut Cake With Chocolate Ganache And Single-Malt Scotch Syrup
description: The combination of chestnuts, chocolate and single-malt Scotch is powerful, so you’ll need to frost this with milk chocolate instead of the usual bittersweet. The milk chocolate ganache tempers the Scotch and mellows the chestnuts, and brings the whole dessert together harmoniously. The cake itself is almost a meringue. Use your best single-malt for this — a lesser one will make for a good but not great result.

title: Cider and Maple Tart
description: Apple cider is used alongside raisins and maple syrup in this tart's custardy filling. Try it for a change of pace at Thanksgiving.

title: Duck Breasts With Honey and Mustard
Honey Focaccia With Apple, Figs and Ricotta
Commander's Palace Duck, Wild Mushroom And Andouille File Gumbo
Gloria Slater's Stuffed Veal Pocket With Oyster Dressing
Sweet Potatoes with Maple and Chipotles
description: This is a Bobby Flay recipe ginned up specifically for Thanksgiving in response to a request from The Times back in 2003. Mr. Flay came through in spades: The sweetness of the potatoes is amplified by maple syrup, then taken in a completely different direction by the addition of fiery chipotle sauce. Sour cream knits the dish together perfectly.

title: Brussels Sprouts With Pancetta
description: This recipe came to The Times in 2003 from Suzanne Goin, the Los Angeles restaurateur whose braised vegetables are a hallmark of her cuisine. It is a marvelously flavorful dish, rich with garlic and salty pancetta. It is one to keep.

title: Creamed Red And White Pearl Onions With Bacon
description: This recipe came to The Times in 2003 from Barbara Lynch, the owner and chef of No. 9 Park in Boston. It is incredibly rich, and remarkably good. If you don't have time to blanch and peel the onions, feel free to use frozen pearl onions in a pinch.

title: Winter Squash Braised in Cider
description: Here, sweet delicata squash is braised in cider with balsamic vinegar and rosemary. The amount of the herb may seem like a lot, but it mellows out in the cooking and gives the squash an unmatched savoriness.

title: Corn Pudding With Herb-Braised Chanterelles And Spicy Greens
Wild Rice With Mushrooms, Cranberries And Walnuts
Braised Celery Hearts With Tomato And Olives
Roasted Maple-Glazed Baby Carrots With Dried Grapes
Mixed Mushroom And Sweet Potato Stuffing
Sweet Potato Pie
description: This mildly-sweet version of the classic Southern pie has a crisp crust and a filling that's surprisingly light. It's rich with egg and boldly spiced with nutmeg, but as fluffy as chiffon (a quality owed to the baking powder in the filling). This means you'll probably have room for two (or three) pieces.

title: Southern Greens
description: How one cooks greens says much about where and how a Southerner grew up. Seasoning, length of cooking time and how to tenderize older greens are often points of debate. Here, the Yankee food writer Amanda Hesser traveled to Georgia and brought back a version that combines the bite of mustard greens with the vegetal heartiness of collards and gives them both depth with ham hocks. Her trick for melding the flavors is a bit of sugar, which is a nice

title: Rabbit in White Wine and Mustard Sauce
Karen's Sausage, Black Olive and Walnut Stuffing
Nigella Lawson's Meatloaf
description: Meatloaf is the quintessential comfort food, the antithesis of fancy restaurant fare. Eat it hot with creamy mashed potatoes or, for greater ease on the cook's part, with baked potatoes and a bowl of chive-flecked sour cream.

title: Polenta And Orange Upside-Down Cake
description: This light but satisfying fruit and cornmeal upside-down cake is a dish that can be shopped for at lunch and cooked without too much fanfare after work.

title: Curried Sweet Potato Soup With Apricots
Thai Turkey And Kaffir Lime Salad
Craig Claiborne’s Ambrosia
description: This mixture of oranges, bananas, grated coconut and sugar is a dessert that is considered by many to be as Southern as magnolias and mint juleps. Craig Claiborne brought this recipe to The Times in 1987 after spending Thanksgiving at the Elgin mansion house, a Greek Revival-style home, in Natchez, Miss., built between 1840 and 1855, and owned by Dr. William Calhoun and his wife, Ruth Ellen. Ethel Banta, Ms. Calhoun's sister, contributed this recipe.

title: Rack of Lamb With Sage Crust
Brook Trout Roasted With Sage, Walnuts and Bacon
Bruschetta With White Bean Puree and Fried Sage Leaves
Roasted Potatoes With Sage and Garlic
Phil Ponzek's Meat and Potato Stuffing
Oyster, Bread and Spinach Stuffing
ingredients: Salt, black pepper and cayenne pepper

title: Corn Bread, Wild Mushroom and Pecan Stuffing
Ginger Pumpkin Pie With Pumpkin Seed Crust
Pumpkin Pie With Rum and Cream
Cranberry-Pecan Cobbler
description: This recipe came to The Times in a 1999 article by Florence Fabricant in which she argued for replacing the ubiquitous Thanksgiving pie with a cobbler. Why? The pastry stays crisp, there's a greater fruit-to-crust ratio and perhaps most importantly, it's easier. Here, two Thanksgiving favorites – cranberries and pecans – are piled into a baking dish, topped with cornmeal biscuits then baked until golden. (This can be made early in the day and reheated to serve warm. Or it can be frozen, then defrosted and warmed, but is best if not refrigerated overnight.)

title: Roasted Stuffed Pumpkin
description: The quantity of rice specified in the recipe is what I needed for the pumpkin I stipulate, but I should say two things here. One is that you might not find (or want) a pumpkin of exactly the same weight. The other is that different pumpkins have different-size cavities. The easiest way to find out how much rice you need is as follows:

title: Monster Halloween Cookies
description: The cookies here have none of the pumpkin's autumnal majesty, but Halloween is not one of the most dignified of festivals. Studded with colored candies (delicious if they are peanut-filled, too), these treats are an amazing way to end a grown-up supper, and a very useful way to keep a roomful of boisterous children happy.

title: Butternut Squash Soup
description: This simple, creamy (but not cream-laden) butternut squash soup gets greater depth of flavor from sherry that is stirred in with the stock. If you’d rather not use sherry or don’t have it on hand, omit it and use an additional 1/2 cup of stock; your soup will be less complex, but it will still have that rich, sweet squash flavor.

title: Spiced Chutney Of Cranberry and Pineapple
Pumpkin Pie With Fresh Ginger and Nutmeg
Sweet Potato Casserole
description: This version of the classic Thanksgiving side dish forgoes the traditional marshmallow topping for a generous sprinkle of brown sugar, butter and pecans. You get crunchy, soft and sweet all in one glorious bite.

title: Roasted Garlic Noodle Cake
description: This amazingly flavorful dinner cake came to The Times from Allen Susser, a Florida chef. It’s an Americanized and sweetly garlicky version of noodle kugel. With white and green fettuccine, it makes a festive spring or holiday presentation, rich and firm, that can hold its own at the center of the table.

title: Cold Shrimp With Warm Cocktail Sauce
Fennel With Olive Oil Dipping Sauce
Figs Stuffed With Goat Cheese
description: Here's a super-simple appetizer. Fresh figs are halved and stuffed with any creamy, flavorful cheese. A good blue works, but creamy goat cheese, drizzled with balsamic vinegar, is even more crowd-pleasing.

title: Real Sour Cream Onion Dip
description: Why make this classic dip with dried onion soup mix when it's almost as easy, and far more delicious, to make it from scratch?

title: Alice Waters’s Cranberry Upside-Down Cake
description: This recipe requires a little extra effort – you have to whip the egg whites separately and then fold them into the batter - but the reward is a light, ethereal cake topped with glistening, caramelized cranberries. Serve with a dollop of whipped cream, and prepare yourself for accolades.

title: Roast Breast of Turkey With Cranberry-Wine Sauce
Mushroom and Kasha Stuffing
recipe_yield: Five cups, enough for 10 pounds of poultry

title: Pumpernickel Fruit Stuffing
recipe_yield: Four cups stuffing, enough for about eight pounds of poultry

title: Celery-Root Puree
description: Last Thanksgiving, Susy Davidson, food editor of Food & Wine magazine, prepared this wonderful celery-root puree in the microwave oven. This cooking method makes for a richer-tasting puree.

title: Prune And Almond Tart
description: Until my move to France, I really didn't feel one way or the other about prunes. But as I've traveled the country, I've discovered the wonders of this rich dried fruit. Something happens to the prunes in this tart as they bake, turning them into almost a sweet, compact candy. Be sure to make a good, strong tea (I used about one tablespoon of loose Earl Grey tea leaves to the two cups of water) for soaking the prunes.

title: Roast Pheasant Stuffed With Chestnut Bread Dressing
Edna Lewis’s Sweet Potatoes Baked With Lemon
Cranberry Chutney
description: This chunky and bright, cardamom-scented, honey-sweetened chutney is loaded with fresh cranberries, green apple and dried apricots. The best part? It comes together in under a half hour.

title: From Beans To Apples Cranberry Beans With Tomatoes and Herbs
Turkey Stuffing
recipe_yield: Enough to stuff two 12-pound turkeys, with plenty left over

title: Ginger Butterscotch Sauce
description: This recipe came to The Times from the pastry chef Pichet Ong, who developed it when he worked at Spice Market and 66 in New York. He served it over a kabocha squash pie with a lime graham cracker crust, but it would go equally well over cheesecake, key lime pie or chess pie. It takes about a half-hour of your time, and will add a buttery note to any dessert.

title: Turkey With Prune Walnut and Celery Stuffing
Porcini Bread Stuffing
description: When it comes to Thanksgiving stuffing, a passionate attachment to one's own family recipe, combined with a healthy suspicion of other stuffings, has become part of the holiday ritual. This one, which includes porcini mushrooms, Cognac, raisins and fresh rosemary, comes from Julia Moskin's family, and is prepared with great ceremony by her uncle Julian M. Cohen. To make it vegetarian, simply use vegetable stock rather than chicken.

title: Rich Cornbread Dressing
description: This luxurious Thanksgiving dressing is almost a bread pudding, with cornbread, eggs, celery, onion, a pint of oysters and lots of butter and heavy cream. If the oysters prove to be too controversial for your family, simply leave them out.

title: Dessert Vinaigrette For Figs
description: Vinaigrettes lend lightness and sparkle to food, but they generally land before the dessert course. But here, a warm orange vinaigrette livens up figs for a light and delicious dessert. This easy recipe, which was inspired by one from Michael Moorhouse, the pastry chef at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, comes together quickly.

title: Giblet Gravy
description: While the turkey is in the oven, get some rest — and make the gravy. Giblet gravy requires the cook to use the neck, gizzard and heart of the bird to make deeply flavored stock, which is then combined with the pan drippings, a bit of flour and wine or brandy. Finally, the cooked neck, gizzard and heart are finely chopped and added to the rich, savory gravy, to make for a more interesting texture.

title: Fettuccine With Sausage And Fried Sage Leaves
Brussels Sprouts And Potato Gratin With Taleggio
Gratin of Brussels Sprouts With Parmesan
Brown Rice And Pecan Stuffing
recipe_yield: About 8 cups, enough for a 12-pound turkey
